title: Former NRL star Ian Hindmarsh wishes he gambled his money away instead of buying dairy farm
text:
A former NRL player says he wishes he gambled his money away rather than becoming a dairy farmer as the drought has destroyed his business.

Ian Hindmarsh, who used to be the second-rower for the Parramatta Eels, has almost lost all the money he earned during his eight-year stint as a professional rugby league player.

The father-of-two was fulfilling his dream when he purchased the 400-acre property in Cowra, in Central West NSW, in 2002, The Daily Telegraph reported.

However, he now claims he regrets that decision.

The father-of-two was fulfilling his dream and continuing the family business after purchasing the 400-acre property in Cowra, in Central West NSW

With a 170-year legacy to continue, Hindmarsh said he did not want his two children to continue on with the dying family business, due to the growing costs from the drought

'I may as well have gambled away the money from playing football, because at least I would have had a life away from the farm,' the 42-year-old said.

'If I didn't build a dairy on my farm, I'd be debt free and I could have a life.'

With a 170-year legacy to continue, Hindmarsh said he did not want his two children to continue on with the dying family business, due to the growing costs from the drought.

He revealed that prices to push on with the dairy farming had soared by 40 per cent, and with 330 cows left he expect the bank to take ownership of the farm.

Hindmarsh took out a bank loan to assist with buying rye grass, wheat, lucerene and grain.

Ian Hindmarsh, who used to be the second-rower for the Parramatta Eels, has lost all the money he earned during his eight-year stint as a professional rugby league player

In line with his struggle, Hindmarsh has also already sold 70 milking cows, while the cost of his remaining cows plunged a whopping half-a-million, the publication reported.

He said he can't afford to sell the off and invest in other animals because he and his wife are too in deep with the debt.

'My wife and I have too much debt to retain our farm, so we'll have to sell everything and we won't have the money to buy back in.'

authors: Sahar Mourad For Daily Mail Australia
